xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels

Class KernelFunction

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels.KernelFunction
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    RealFunction
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BiweightKernel, CosineArchKernel, EpanechnikowKernel, GaussianKernel, TransformedKernelFunction, TriweightKernel, UniformKernel

    public abstract class KernelFunction
extends Object
implements RealFunction
    This class provides the usage of kernel functions for statistical purposes. Especially in nonparametric statistics kernel estimators play an important role. In accordance to the chosen kernel function the resulting kernel estimators are smooth and inherit the basic properties of the kernel function. For this function different choices are possible whereas a pdf is advisable.
    The statistical analysis of kernel estimators is much simpler than for histograms whereas histograms are another relevant topic in nonparametric statistics. For statistical applications often some parameters respectively constants of the kernel function are required, e.g., the mean.
    Fulfilling those requirements, this class provides an interface for one-dimensional kernel functions and their most important constants.
    Every implementing kernel function must provide the constant values of its mean, its square root of the 2nd moment about the mean and its roughness. These informations are required for computing the bandwidths for kernel estimators (e.g. for the kernel density estimator).
    For further informations about kernel estimators and especially their usage in statistical purposes see [Sco92] David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. John Wiley & Sons, inc. 1992.
    See Also:
    RealFunction, KernelBandwidths, AbstractKernelDensityEstimator, AbstractKernelCDF

      • r

        public double r()
        Returns the roughness of the kernel function.
        Returns:
        roughness of the kernel function. See [Sco92] David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. John Wiley & Sons, inc. 1992. pages 131 ff. for further infomation. ( R(f) = integral( f(s)^2 dx) ). See [Sco92] page 281 (notation).
